Rationale: Direct intersection of ML, AD, and microbiome. Primary research area.
ML methods specifically applied to gut microbiome in dementia.
Current method (XGBoost). Looking for optimizations and best practices.
Gradient boosting applications in microbiome studies.
Ensemble methods for AD classification to improve on single XGBoost.
Random forest as alternative/complementary approach.
Neural network approaches for microbiome-AD classification.
Methods for 4.7:1 class imbalance (227 controls, 48 AD cases).
SMOTE variants for handling imbalance in small medical datasets.
Cost-sensitive approaches as alternative to oversampling.
Focal loss for addressing class imbalance in medical ML.
ML methods for small sample sizes (275 samples, 119 patients).
Proper validation to avoid overfitting with small N.
Handling repeated measures (275 samples, 119 patients). Group-level splitting.
GroupKFold strategies to prevent patient-level leakage.
Feature selection methods for high-dimensional microbiome data.
Current method (SHAP). Looking for best practices and alternatives.
ML methods that respect compositional nature of microbiome data (CLR, TSS).
CLR transformation (current method) with ML applications.
Feature interactions for microbiome communities (meta-topics).
Domain-informed features (dysbiosis index, SCFA capacity, etc.).
Hyperparameter tuning strategies for medical ML (current: Optuna).
Optuna best practices and optimization strategies.
Bayesian optimization for hyperparameter search with small N.
Regularization to prevent overfitting in medical datasets.
Model interpretability for clinical acceptance and biological insight.
XAI methods for healthcare applications.
Comparison of explainability methods (LIME vs SHAP).
Feature importance in ensemble models.
Integrating DAA results (LinDA) with ML models.
LDA topics (meta-topics) as ML features.
Community-level features vs individual species in ML.
Species-level features (current) vs genus-level for ML.
ML for identifying microbial biomarkers of AD.
Microbiome-based diagnostic models for AD.
Prognostic models for dementia progression.
Integrating microbiome with clinical covariates (current approach).
Incorporating clinical variables (age, sex, medications, etc.).
Handling confounders (frailty, polypharmacy) in ML models.
Batch effect correction in microbiome ML studies.
Handling missing values in microbiome datasets.
Model calibration for reliable probability estimates.
External validation strategies for medical ML models.
Reproducibility challenges and solutions in microbiome ML.
Computational reproducibility best practices.
Appropriate metrics for imbalanced datasets (F1, AUC, precision-recall).
PR curves for imbalanced medical classification (current target).
Uncertainty quantification in medical ML predictions.
Bootstrap methods for ML model uncertainty.
Automated ML for medical datasets as alternative to manual tuning.
Transfer learning approaches for microbiome studies.
Meta-learning for small medical datasets.
Federated learning for multi-center microbiome studies.
